issues.description: The template and problem statement present a program with a 'main' entry point, a .data section containing the 'hello' string, and an extern printf call (template: global main, extern printf, push/call printf). The solution repository, however, uses a different entry symbol (global CMAIN / CMAIN:) and omits the .data section and the printf call, instead only showing arithmetic on registers and ret. This cross-artifact structural mismatch (entry symbol name and presence/absence of data/IO code) can confuse students: they may follow the template instructions and expect the solution to show the same program structure (especially when using the Makefile or expecting printf-based output), or they may incorrectly assume multiple independent fixes are required. The core pedagogical task (change 'ecc' to 'ecx') is consistent, but the differing entry label and missing data/printf in the solution create an unintentional structural inconsistency.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution repository match the template's program structure so students can directly compare them: use the same global entry symbol (global main / label 'main'), include the .data section with the 'hello' string, and show the printf call sequence (push hello / call printf / add esp,4 / ret). Alternatively, document in the problem statement that the solution is provided for a different assembler/runtime (SASM) which uses 'CMAIN' and different conventions, so students understand why the solution's layout differs.

issues.description: The template uses the identifier 'ecc' in the assembly instruction (a typographical error) while the solution uses the correct register name 'ecx' and the problem statement instructs to change 'ecc' to 'ecx'. This inconsistent identifier (ecc vs ecx) for the same conceptual entity (the ECX CPU register) can cause compilation failure and unnecessary confusion for students trying to map the problem instructions to the provided template and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the typographical error in the template by replacing 'ecc' with 'ecx' (e.g., change line 'add eax, ecc' to 'add eax, ecx') and update any related comments so all artifacts consistently reference 'ecx'.
